Content:
probably just the music store -- and probably just some small part of it.

Author: Ultrapreneur
Title: Taking votes on Anywhere.FM
Content:
So I just visited the Anywhere.FM beta site which is funded by Y Combinator, and I must admit I was pretty impressed with what I saw. Their concept is pretty simple, have users upload their music, then be able to access it from anywhere. When I'm not working on the next big thing I work as a consultant for military companies, and I'm not allowed to bring in items such as camera phones with music players, or anything that can store sensitive data.. i.e. music player with USB interface. I always enjoy listening to music while I work, and Anywhere.FM has created the perfect solution for me and probably alot of others.

I'm putting my money on the guys at Anywhere.FM (nice job)

what's your thoughts?

Author: ph0rque
Content:
Before I resigned, I used to work in a hardware startup: i-conserve (i-conserve.com) that I founded. Basically, i-conserve is working on a wireless sensor suite using ZigBee to measure, control, and conserve energy.

Why do you ask?

Author: drm237
Title: Startup pace: Go Fast, but Don't Hurry
Content: My team is sure to crack a smirk every time someone asks me what our timeline is. They smirk because they know exactly how I'm going to respond. I say, "we like to go fast, but we don't hurry".

Author: gibsonf1
Content: My take on the article is that what he needs/wants is a web 2.0 application that would save him time, like a business productivity app.

Author: eastsidegringo
Title: Slow Down to Increase Office Productivity
Content: We rush so fast we miss it all. Everyone knows how busy we all are nowadays. The TrackSuit CEO wants to shoot for the stars and still spend his life with his family, and somehow this seems to me the most reasonable thing in the world. How to achieve this?\n

Author: bmccarthy
Title: Web 2.0 Means User-Driven
Content: A lot of companies find themselves in the position of having forums, discussion groups and developer communities that are not sponsored by them or hosted under their domain. A lot of them probably don't take these networks seriously. This is wishful thinking. We've always known that word of mouth and independent opinions are more powerful than formal marketing programs. Web 2.0 is just the latest reflection of that reality.

Content:
Yeah, this seems to be the only question. The interface is wonderful and it's instantly useful to me, but I can't imagine this will be allowed to stand as is.

Though I would have said the same thing about YouTube...

Author: rms
Content: I don't think it's a very good comparison. Everyone can "view source" and see the html code used to display the site. They can't get the actual code that creates the app's functionality, in the same way that you can't decompile an MP3 and get the instrumental tracks that make it up.

Author: dfens
Content: So when you're done making your web app everyone can have a copy of the code ... right?

Author: epi0Bauqu
Content: What is the difference between what you are saying and a simple web form that emails you the answers, or even simpler, just putting the questions in an email?

Author: ashu
Title: Buxfer + Amazon = Transfer money online (Free till Aug 31)
Content:
With Amazon Payments, you can accrue balances in an online account (similar to your Paypal account balance). Transfers involving Amazon accounts are instantaneously processed as well.

You can read more about it at: \nhttp://www.buxfer.com/blog/2007/08/03/buxfer-amazon-settle-y...

Regardless of what this means for Buxfer, we think it's a good step forward in challenging the Paypal monopoly.
